Localisation.report_string:
--- Localisation ---
Agree with lesions involving:
- left optic nerve (cranial nerve II) and left midbrain.
  
Remaining signs are better explained by:
- right medulla lesion

Than the suggested:
- cervical spinal cord.

Differential diagnosis.report_string:
--- Differential diagnosis ---
Correctly included: Multiple sclerosis
  
These suggested differentials are reasonable:

- Posterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm causing left CN III palsy; Neuromyelitis Optica Spectrum Disorder; MOG Antibody–Associated Disease; Orbital Apex/Cavernous Sinus Syndrome (e.g., Tolosa–Hunt, cavernous sinus thrombosis); Neurosarcoidosis; Primary CNS Vasculitis (including SLE/ANCA-associated); Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy

ft_diagnoses_raw: Posterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm causing left CN III palsy
Orbital Apex/Cavernous Sinus Syndrome (e.g., Tolosa–Hunt, cavernous sinus thrombosis)
additional_diagnoses: Posterior Communicating Artery Aneurysm causing left CN III palsy
Orbital Apex/Cavernous Sinus Syndrome (e.g., Tolosa–Hunt, cavernous sinus thrombosis)

Investigations.report_string:
--- Investigations ---
Agree with all suggestions.

- MRI including the Brain and Orbits and CSF test for Oligoclonal Bands would potentially inform a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

ft_proposed_investigations: CT Angiogram Head (Circle of Willis) – urgent
MRI Brain and Orbits with gadolinium
CSF oligoclonal bands with paired serum
CSF culture and viral PCR panel

Management.report_string:
--- Management ---
Steroids: Appropriate decision to consider but delay treatment.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (Urine: Leucocytes ++, Blood +).

- Presenting complaint is not specified, so no indication whether this is related to MS.

- Timing of current symptoms not specified, so no indication whether this is a recent issue or old deficit.

DMTs: Appropriate decision to consider but delay treatment.
  
Correctly identified the following:

- Need confirmation of MS diagnosis.
  
Additional factors not mentioned:

- Evidence of potential active intercurrent infection (Urine: Leucocytes ++, Blood +).

- Need a pregnancy test result.

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Hospital admission with frequent neurological observations and fall precautions
reasons: Risk of neurological deterioration
Unsteady gait with spasticity
Facilitates urgent imaging and multidisciplinary input

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Corneal protection (lubricating drops/ointment; eye patch if exposure)
reasons: Severe left ptosis/ophthalmoplegia risks exposure keratopathy
Symptomatic relief of diplopia if present

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Mechanical venous thromboembolism prophylaxis (intermittent pneumatic compression)
reasons: Reduced mobility from spastic paraparesis
Avoids anticoagulation before excluding aneurysm

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Start after CTA/MRA excludes aneurysm and infection
Treats suspected inflammatory demyelinating relapse
Best efficacy when started within 14 days of relapse

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Endovascular coiling or surgical clipping of a posterior communicating artery aneurysm (if confirmed)
reasons: Initiate immediately once aneurysm is identified on urgent angiography
Prevents rupture and treats compressive third-nerve palsy
Improves mobility and reduces falls
Addresses spasticity and ataxic gait early
Introduce after acute diagnostic phase
Adjust based on response and side effects

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Long-term disease-modifying therapy for MS (agent based on MRI/CSF and risk profile, e.g., ocrelizumab or natalizumab)
reasons: Start only after diagnostic confirmation and exclusion of mimics
Requires baseline screening and counselling

ft_full_plan_parsed.treatment: Proton pump inhibitor and bone protection while on high-dose steroids
reasons: Begin when steroids are initiated
Reduces gastrointestinal and bone-related adverse effects

ft_plan.treatment: High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1 g daily for 3–5 days
reasons: Start after CTA/MRA excludes aneurysm and infection
Treats suspected inflammatory demyelinating relapse
Best efficacy when started within 14 days of relapse
